item.title: Public AI Is the New Multilateralism
item.description: In the 1970s, European governments worked together to create an aircraft manufacturer capable of competing with the US firm Boeing. As a handful of private companies in Shenzhen and Silicon Valley race to entrench their AI dominance, similarly bold cooperation among middle powers has become imperative.

item.title: The New “China Shock” Is Hitting Poor Countries the Hardest
item.description: China’s continued dominance in low-skill export sectors reflects not just efficiency, but deliberate policy choices that prevent poorer countries from climbing the development ladder. If it truly aspires to global leadership, it must stop tilting the playing field in its own favor.

item.title: Europe Must Address Its Disastrous Demographics
item.description: International institutions and think tanks have published detailed warnings about Europe’s demographic decline since the turn of the century, but to no avail. Political and business leaders have studiously avoided planning for population aging, even though it poses a serious threat to financial stability.

item.title: Are We in a Financial Bubble?
item.description: While there is ample reason to believe that AI-driven investments are in bubble territory, the real question is when – and how – the end might come. For anyone hazarding a guess, the lessons of past bubbles, combined with key financial-market indicators, offer a useful guide.

item.title: America’s Real Enemy Within
item.description: By politicizing the US military and deploying it at home for his partisan purposes, US President Donald Trump has created a clear and present danger to American democracy. Americans would do well to remember why the country's founders worried so deeply about this very threat.

item.title: The West’s “Free Palestine” Movement Isn’t Helping
item.description: Contrary to the claims of Western progressives, anti-Israel movements cannot be tidily separated from antisemitism. But Jews are not the only ones being hurt by the West's "Free Palestine" movement; the Palestinians' interests are also being undermined.

item.title: AI Is Hollowing Out Higher Education
item.description: While the AI industry claims its models can “think,” “reason,” and “learn,” their supposed achievements rest on marketing hype and stolen intellectual labor. In reality, AI erodes academic freedom, weakens critical reading, and subordinates the pursuit of knowledge to corporate interests.

item.title: Can Humanity Fix What It Has Broken?
item.description: As climate-driven disasters intensify, the costs are falling hardest on the poor, underscoring the urgent need for a just transition to clean energy and a net-zero-emissions economy. Although multilateralism is no longer in vogue, it remains the only viable path forward.

item.title: The Coming US Financial Crisis
item.description: While US President Donald Trump has regularly roiled markets, investors have failed to account adequately for escalating risks to the US financial system. With market participants chasing short-term profits, and regulators considering measures that would further erode financial stability, it is only a matter of time until cracks begin to appear.

item.title: The Big Picture
Will the AI Bubble Trigger a Financial Crisis?
item.description: Experts might not expect a stock-market crash to cause a financial crisis, but what if they are wrong? With leverage built up in so many parts of the system and asset-price movements so closely correlated, the current US financial system looks like a tinder box just waiting for a spark to land on it.

item.title: Democracy and the Case for Protecting Livelihoods
item.description: In a democratic society, those who suffer permanent job losses because of public policy will naturally consider their plight unjust, and may eventually form an electorally disruptive critical mass. Even if one does not see a strictly economic reason to redress their grievances, there most certainly is a political one.

item.title: Putin Is Out of Options
item.description: It is now clear that Russia’s army cannot get the job done in Ukraine, and that Donald Trump cannot force Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky into submission as long as European financial support for his government holds. Whether Russian leaders realize it or not, they have no path to victory.

item.title: The Problem with America’s Health-Care Subsidies
item.description: The US federal government shutdown has become a standoff over health care that will likely end with some sort of extension of the temporary health-insurance subsidies adopted during the pandemic. But that would not address the larger problem of America’s high health-care costs – to say nothing of its fiscal imbalance.

item.title: Electricity Will Decide the AI Race
item.description: By advancing open AI models and investing in renewable-energy capacity, China is creating an energy-compute flywheel: more clean power enables more compute, which in turn optimizes the grid. This puts China at a distinct advantage vis-à-vis the West, where energy constraints are creating digital bottlenecks.

item.title: Harnessing AI While Supporting Democracy
item.description: From deepfakes and black-box algorithms to new tools to improve government effectiveness and civic engagement, AI is already reshaping democracies. To meet this moment, we must help democracies adopt AI while ensuring governments establish essential guardrails to protect rights, privacy, agency, and trust.

item.title: In Defense of Encryption
item.description: The European Union’s proposed Child Sexual Abuse Regulation creates a dangerous illusion of safety that does little to protect children. Worse, by compromising the confidentiality and privacy provided by end-to-end encryption, the EU's approach creates new vulnerabilities that could put users everywhere at risk.

item.title: What Really Works Against Youth Crime?
item.description: Research shows that, when it comes to deterring crime, the severity of punishment – the length of a prison sentence – matters far less than whether punishment is swift and certain. This finding holds true for adults, but the difference is especially stark for teenagers, given their higher impulsivity.

item.title: Is Economics Promoting Inequality?
item.description: Mainstream economics has often underestimated the critical role of trust and cooperation in enabling prosperity. As a result, it has justified and even encouraged the greed, exploitation, and extreme inequality that are eroding political accountability, contributing to rising nationalism, and undermining human well-being.

item.title: Trump’s Manifest Destiny
item.description: US President Donald Trump appears committed to extending America's imperialist legacy and channeling a martial ethos that can be traced back to the Spanish-American War of 1898, when the US "liberated" Cuba and the Philippines from Spanish colonial rule. If past is prologue, there can be little doubt that it will end badly.
